column1: Did you get those yoga pants on sale? because at my house theyre 100% off
column3: In the context of the joke, off can mean not on (as in removal or discount) and away from (spatial or physical distance).
column4: She took her shoes off before entering the house.
column5: The dog ran off into the distance after chasing a squirrel.

column1: How do trees access the internet? they log on
column3: Log can refer to a record or entry in computing (logging onto the internet) and can also refer to a piece of wood (a tree log).
column4: The carpenter used a large log to build the table.
column5: She had to log her hours for the project submission last night.

column1: A midget dressed up as a circuit board on halloween night died you could say he short-circuited
column3: Short can refer to something small in height (a short person) and can also mean a failure in an electrical circuit (short-circuit).
column4: The child was notably short for his age compared to his classmates.
column5: The power went out because of a short in the wiring.

column1: What do you call a cat who steals someones identity? an impawster.
column3: Paw refers to the foot of a cat (animal feature) and can also play on the word impersonator (in the context of stealing identity).
column4: The cat extended its paw to swat at a toy.
column5: The imposter tried to fool everyone but was soon discovered.

column1: Please note that while I tried to follow your criteria closely, the humor in the jokes often relies on elements beyond simple wordplay, and context can affect interpretations.
